name: ls
desc: Lists files in the current directory
definition: Lists all files and folders in the current directory. Equivalent to `dir` on Windows or `ls` on Unix.

name: cd
desc: Changes the current working directory
definition: Use `cd <folder>` to navigate to a folder or `cd ..` to move up one directory.

name: history
desc: Shows or manages your command history
definition:
Displays a list of previously executed commands, similar to Bash's `history`. Supports filtering, clearing, and command re-execution.

Usage:
  history                → shows all previously used commands
  history -n <number>    → shows only the last N commands
  history -c             → clears all stored command history
  !<number>              → re-runs the command at that history number

Examples:
  history                → lists all commands with numbering
  history -n 5           → displays the 5 most recent commands
  history -c             → clears all command history
  !3                     → re-executes the 3rd command in the history list

Details:
• Commands are automatically recorded whenever executed, including both manual and auto-run commands.
• The `!<number>` syntax allows you to quickly repeat any past command by its listed index.
• History persists only for the current session.

Tip: Combine `history -n` with `!<number>` to quickly re-run recent commands (e.g., `history -n 5` then `!5`).

name: ip
desc: Displays local or public IP information
definition:
Shows network interface details, including local IPv4 addresses and the system's public IP. Works similarly to `ipconfig` on Windows or `ifconfig` on Unix.

Usage:
  ip                  → displays hostname, local IPv4, and public IP
  ip -s               → lists all active network interfaces and their IPv4 addresses

Examples:
  ip                  → shows your device hostname, local network IP, and external IP address
  ip -s               → lists all connected adapters (Ethernet, Wi-Fi, etc.) and their IPv4 addresses

Details:
• The `-s` flag enumerates all active network interfaces using the system’s socket and psutil libraries.
• The default mode (`ip`) attempts to retrieve your public IP using online APIs like api.ipify.org and icanhazip.com.
• Works on Windows, macOS, and Linux.
• Automatically falls back gracefully if no internet connection is available.

Tip: Use `ip -s` before running LAN tools like `opendrop` to confirm which interface and address your system is using.

name: goback
desc: Returns to the previously visited directory
definition:
Quickly switches back to the last directory you were in, similar to the Unix `cd -` command.

Usage:
  goback               → returns to the previous working directory

Examples:
  cd C:\Users\Owen\Desktop
  cd C:\Users\Owen\Projects
  goback               → moves back to C:\Users\Owen\Desktop

Details:
• PyNixShell automatically records the last directory each time you use `cd`.
• Running `goback` swaps your current directory with the previously visited one, allowing you to toggle back and forth.
• Works across all supported platforms (Windows, macOS, Linux).

Tip: Use `goback` when navigating between two folders frequently — it acts like a quick directory toggle button.

name: option
desc: Displays an interactive options menu for a file or folder
definition:
Opens an interactive file options menu in the terminal that mimics a desktop right-click menu. From here, you can perform actions like Open, Edit, Delete, Copy, Paste, Rename, and more.

Usage:
  option <filename or foldername>

Examples:
  option notes.txt
  option Documents

Available Actions:
• Open — Opens the file or folder using the system default program.
• Edit — Opens the file in the built-in Nano text editor.
• Delete — Removes the selected file or folder permanently.
• Copy / Paste — Copies and pastes files or directories within PyNixShell.
• Rename — Renames the file or folder directly from the terminal.
• New Folder / New File — Creates new files or folders in the same directory.
• Open Terminal Here — Opens PyNixShell’s terminal in the target directory.
• Properties — Displays detailed admin and sharing properties for the file (Windows only).
• Open File Location — Opens the directory containing the file in the system’s file explorer.

Details:
• Works on both files and folders.
• On Windows, the Properties option opens the native file properties dialog via ShellExecuteEx.
• On Unix-based systems, fallback actions (open, edit, etc.) are handled via `subprocess.call(["open", path])`.

Tip: Use `option` as a convenient GUI-like replacement for multiple manual commands like `open`, `nano`, `rm`, and `cp` — all in one place.

name: pwd
desc: Prints the current directory
definition: Displays the absolute path of your current working directory.

name: touch
desc: Creates a new file
definition: Usage: `touch filename.txt` — creates a blank file in the current directory.

name: mkdir
desc: Creates a new folder
definition: Usage: `mkdir foldername` — creates a directory at the current path.

name: rm
desc: Removes files or folders
definition: Deletes a file or folder permanently. Use carefully — there is no undo.

name: rfpt
desc: Refreshes PyNixShell to apply updates
definition: Reloads the current shell environment without closing the terminal.

name: shutdown
desc: Safely shuts down the system
definition: Displays a confirmation dialog before shutting down your system.

name: restart
desc: Restarts the computer
definition: Displays a confirmation dialog and then reboots the system.

name: neofetch
desc: Displays PyNixShell logo and system info
definition: Shows ASCII art of the PyNix logo and basic system details like OS, CPU, RAM.

name: help
desc: Displays available commands and their descriptions
definition: Lists all commands or provides detailed help for a specific one using `help <command>`.

name: commands
desc: Lists or searches all available commands
definition: Usage: `commands` to list all, or `commands search <keyword>` to filter by topic.

name: ps
desc: Lists running system processes
definition:
Displays a live snapshot of all active processes on your computer, including PID, name, CPU usage, memory usage, and command line.

Usage:
  ps              → shows all processes
  ps -p           → shows only Python-related processes
  ps -s <name>    → searches for any process by partial or full name (case-insensitive)

Examples:
  ps -p           → filters to only show python.exe or pythonw.exe
  ps -s chrome    → shows all Chrome-related processes
  ps -s vscode    → shows all processes matching 'vscode'

name: du
desc: Shows disk usage for files and folders
definition:
Calculates and displays the total disk space used by files and directories, similar to the Unix `du` command.

Usage:
  du                  → displays disk usage for each directory and subdirectory
  du -s <path>        → shows only the total disk usage for the specified path
  du -f <file>        → shows the size of a single file only

Examples:
  du                  → prints usage for all folders recursively under the current directory
  du -s Documents     → prints the total space used by the 'Documents' folder
  du -f image.png     → displays only the size of 'image.png'

Flags:
  -s                  → summary mode (only total size)
  -f                  → file mode (check one specific file)

Tip: Use this command to identify which folders or files are taking up the most space. Combine with `df` to get a complete view of your disk usage.

name: df
desc: Displays total and available disk space
definition:
Shows detailed disk usage information for all available drives or mounted volumes. Works similarly to the Unix `df` command.

Usage:
  df                  → displays disk usage for all available drives
  df -h               → displays disk usage in human-readable format (KB, MB, GB)

Examples:
  df                  → lists all drives with total, used, and free space in bytes
  df -h               → lists drives with formatted sizes (e.g., 120.5 GB, 15.3 GB)

Columns:
  Filesystem          → the drive or mount name
  Size                → total storage size
  Used                → amount of space currently used
  Avail               → remaining available space
  Use%                → percentage of space used
  Mounted on          → the mount or drive location

Tip: Use `df -h` for an easier-to-read overview of your storage capacity on Windows or Unix.

name: findgit
desc: Finds all Git repositories on the system
definition:
Scans your local drives or specified directory to locate all folders containing a `.git` subdirectory, identifying Git repositories automatically.

Usage:
  findgit         → scans the default user directory for Git repositories
  findgit <path>  → scans a specific folder or drive for `.git` repositories

Examples:
  findgit         → searches within the user's home or projects directory
  findgit D:\Code → scans the D:\Code folder for repositories

Tip: Useful for quickly finding all Git projects on your system or verifying repository locations.

name: programs
desc: Lists all installed or recognized applications
definition:
Displays a list of all applications and executable programs available to launch within PyNixShell. This includes built-in tools, linked executables, and registered scripts.

Usage:
  programs          → lists all recognized applications
  programs -r       → refreshes the program cache and updates the list

Examples:
  programs          → shows all launchable apps (e.g., terminal, notepad, browser)
  programs -r       → updates the list after adding new apps or executables

Tip: Use this command to view programs available for quick launching with the `launch` command.

name: launch
desc: Launches an installed or registered program
definition:
Opens a specific application or executable that is recognized by PyNixShell. Works similarly to the Linux `open` or Windows `start` command.

Usage:
  launch <program>      → launches the specified program
  launch <program> <args> → runs the program with optional arguments

Examples:
  launch notepad         → opens Notepad
  launch chrome https://intnix.app → opens Google Chrome with a URL
  launch terminal        → opens a new PyNixShell terminal window

Tip: Use the `programs` command first to see the list of available apps.

name: kill
desc: Terminates a running process by its PID
definition:
Forcefully ends a running process using its PID (process ID). Works similar to the Unix `kill` command.

Usage:
  kill <PID>       → terminates the specified process
  kill -f <PID>    → forcefully terminates the process (if normal kill fails)

Examples:
  kill 1234        → stops the process with ID 1234
  kill -f 5678     → forcefully ends the process with ID 5678

⚠️ Warning: Use with caution. Terminating essential system processes may cause instability or loss of data.

name: opendrop
desc: Runs the OpenDrop LAN sharing program
definition:
Launches the OpenDrop Python-based local network sharing utility, which allows file transfer and chat between devices on the same LAN.

Usage:
  opendrop         → starts the OpenDrop program using the default Python interpreter

Details:
  OpenDrop enables peer discovery, file sending, and LAN-based communication without requiring an internet connection.
  It can host or join local sessions for sharing files securely between nearby computers.

Tip: Make sure `opendrop.py` or `opendropUnix.py` is in your current directory before running this command.

name: cat
desc: Displays the contents of a file
definition:
Outputs the full contents of a file directly in the terminal. Works like the Unix `cat` command.

Usage:
  cat <filename>       → displays the file's contents
  cat <path>           → displays the file at the given path

Examples:
  cat notes.txt        → prints everything inside 'notes.txt'
  cat C:\logs\error.log → displays the contents of 'error.log'

Tip: Use this command to quickly read text files without opening an external editor.

name: clear
desc: Clears the terminal screen
definition:
Usage: clear

Clears the PyNixShell terminal output, similar to the 'clear' command on Unix or 'cls' on Windows. This helps declutter the display without affecting running state or environment variables.

name: rsync
desc: Synchronizes a source file across the system or with a specific target file or folder
definition:
Usage:
  rsync <path/to/source.ext>             → sync all files on system with the same name
  rsync <path/to/source.ext> -t <target> → sync only to a specific file or folder

The 'rsync' command synchronizes identical-named files across the system, or directly to a target file/folder using the '-t' flag.

Features:
• Requires administrator privileges ('sudo rsync').
• System-wide mode searches all drives for files with the same name and extension.
• Targeted mode (-t) syncs only to the specified path.
• Compares file size and hash to skip identical copies.
• Prompts for confirmation before overwriting.

Examples:
  rsync C:\Users\Owen\Desktop\logo.png
  rsync logo.png -t D:\Backup\Assets\logo.png
  rsync settings.json -t D:\Configs

⚠️ Warning:
Use with care — system-wide synchronization may overwrite many files.

name: donut
desc: Displays a smooth spinning ASCII donut animation
definition:
Renders a rotating 3D ASCII donut animation directly in the terminal. The donut spins continuously until stopped by the user.

Usage:
  donut               → starts the donut animation (press ESC to stop)

Examples:
  donut               → displays a spinning donut in the terminal window

Details:
• Uses mathematical rotation and shading to simulate a 3D spinning torus in ASCII form.
• Press the ESC key at any time to stop the animation gracefully.
• The animation runs smoothly in-place using ANSI cursor control (no flickering).
• Fully cross-platform — works on Windows, macOS, and Linux.

Tip: Try running `donut` in fullscreen mode for the best visual effect. Press "ESC" to stop it at any time.

name: grep
desc: Searches for text inside files (like Unix 'grep')
definition:
Usage:
  grep <pattern> <filename>
  grep -i <pattern> <filename>     # case-insensitive

Searches the specified file for lines containing a given text pattern. Displays matching lines with their line numbers. The '-i' flag performs a case-insensitive search.

Examples:
  grep error logs.txt
  grep -i warning server.log

name: head
desc: Shows the first few lines of a file
definition:
Displays the beginning of a file, typically the first 3–10 lines, depending on configuration. Works like the Unix `head` command.

Usage:
  head <filename>      → shows the first 3 lines by default
  head -n <count> <filename> → shows the first N lines

Examples:
  head log.txt         → prints the first 3 lines of 'log.txt'
  head -n 10 report.txt → prints the first 10 lines

Tip: Use this to preview large files or check logs without displaying everything.

name: tail
desc: Displays the last few lines of a file
definition:
Shows the end of a file, typically the last 3–10 lines, depending on configuration. Works like the Unix `tail` command.

Usage:
  tail <filename>          → shows the last 3 lines by default
  tail -n <count> <filename> → shows the last N lines
  tail -f <filename>       → continuously follows file changes in real-time (like log monitoring)

Examples:
  tail log.txt             → prints the last 3 lines of 'log.txt'
  tail -n 10 report.txt    → prints the last 10 lines of 'report.txt'
  tail -f system.log       → keeps printing new lines as they are added to 'system.log'

Tip: Use `tail -f` for monitoring live-updating files such as logs or process outputs.

name: tree
desc: Displays the directory structure in a tree format
definition:
Recursively lists folders and files in a tree-like structure, showing how directories and files are nested. Works similarly to the Unix `tree` command.

Usage:
  tree                  → displays the folder structure of the current directory
  tree <path>           → displays the structure of a specified directory
  tree -L <depth>       → limits the tree depth to a specific number of levels

Examples:
  tree                  → prints all files and folders under the current path
  tree C:\Projects      → shows the directory tree for C:\Projects
  tree -L 2 src         → lists only two levels deep inside the 'src' folder

Tip: Use this command to visualize your project’s folder layout. Combine with `-L` to keep output concise for large directories.

name: view
desc: Displays folder or archive contents without extracting or entering
definition:
Lists all files and folders in a directory or inside a compressed archive.

Usage:
  view                   → lists contents of the current folder
  view <path>            → lists contents of a specific folder
  view -z <file.zip>     → lists files inside a ZIP archive
  view -t <file.tar>     → lists files inside a TAR archive

Details:
• Works for both folders and compressed archives.
• Uses Python’s zipfile and tarfile modules to inspect archive contents.
• Displays file sizes in a human-readable format (KB, MB, GB).

Tip: Combine this with the `ls`, `tree`, or `du` commands to explore files and archive structures easily.

name: csync
desc: Synchronizes and cleans all command files in /commands
definition:
The `csync` command performs a full synchronization of all Python command files inside the `/commands` directory. It automatically reloads modified commands, imports new ones, and removes defunct or deleted commands that no longer exist in their source files.

Usage:
  csync               → reloads, imports, and cleans all external command files

How it Works:
• Recursively scans the `/commands` folder for `.py` files.
• Reloads and reimports any updated command files.
• Removes any commands whose files were deleted or whose `@register_command` decorators were removed.
• Keeps all registered commands in perfect sync with the current file structure.

Examples:
  csync               → performs a complete sync of all available commands

Notes:
- Automatically detects and removes empty or defunct command definitions.
- You can safely modify or delete `.py` command files — running `csync` will reflect those changes instantly.

Tip:
Use `lsc` to verify loaded commands after syncing.

name: mod
desc: Executes a command after a timed delay
definition:
Delays the execution of any command by a specified number of seconds.

Usage:
  mod -t <seconds> <command>

Examples:
  mod -t 5 echo Hello world   → waits 5 seconds, then prints 'Hello world'
  mod -t 10 ls                → waits 10 seconds, then lists files

Features:
• Non-blocking — runs in the background while you continue using the shell.
• Accepts fractional seconds (e.g., 0.5).
• Fully compatible with all PyNixShell commands.

Tip: Combine with other automation commands like 'loop' or 'watch' for delayed workflows.

name: lsc
desc: Lists all external commands and their source files
definition:
Displays information about external command files stored in the /commands directory. It can show currently loaded commands in memory or scan the filesystem for all declared @register_command entries.

Usage:
  lsc                 → lists all active external commands currently loaded
  lsc -c              → scans /commands recursively for all @register_command definitions

Examples:
  lsc                 → shows active commands with their full file paths
  lsc -c              → scans source files to discover all registered commands, even if not currently loaded

Details:
• Normal mode lists active, loaded commands and where they were imported from.
• -c mode searches through each .py file in /commands to detect all registered commands.
• Supports recursive folder scanning (subdirectories inside /commands).

Tip:
Run 'csync' before 'lsc' to ensure your command list is up to date after adding or removing files.

name: ssh
desc: Connect two computers on the same network for chat and file sharing
definition:
Usage:
  ssh host   → start hosting a LAN chat + file session
  ssh join   → discover and connect to a host

Commands inside session:
  help                - show this help
  listfiles           - list shared files
  push <file>         - upload a file to host
  pushdir <folder>    - upload a folder as a zip
  pull <file>         - download a file
  pulldir <folder>    - download a zipped folder
  rmv <name>          - remove a file or folder from host
  exit                - disconnect from session

The ssh command allows peer-to-peer communication and file sharing over LAN between two or more computers running PyNixShell. It automatically detects available hosts using UDP broadcast and connects using TCP sockets for reliable communication.

name: ungit
desc: Removes Git tracking (.git folder) from a directory
definition:
Usage:
  ungit [path]

Completely removes Git tracking from the specified directory or the current one if no path is provided.

Examples:
  ungit            # Removes .git from the current directory
  ungit myproject  # Removes .git from the 'myproject' folder

Details:
- Recursively removes all .git folders, even nested ones.
- Unlocks read-only files before deletion.
- On Windows, terminates any running git.exe process to avoid lock issues.
- Verifies after cleanup to confirm the directory is no longer tracked by Git.

name: newline
desc: Inserts a blank line in the terminal output
definition:
Creates an empty line in the terminal, similar to pressing Enter manually. This is useful for improving readability or visually separating command outputs.

Usage:
  newline               → prints one blank line
  newline <count>       → prints multiple blank lines

Examples:
  newline               → adds one empty line
  newline 3             → adds three empty lines

Tip:
Use 'newline' between commands to keep the terminal display organized when working with long outputs.

name: tar
desc: Creates a TAR archive using the system’s native tar utility
definition:
Combines a folder or file into a .tar archive using the host system’s native tar command.

Usage:
  tar <source_folder> <destination.tar>

Examples:
  tar MyProject backup.tar
  tar Documents archive.tar

Details:
• Uses the built-in 'tar' utility available on Linux, macOS, and Windows 10/11.
• If the system tar tool is unavailable, automatically falls back to Python’s tarfile module.
• The resulting archive preserves directory structure and file metadata.

Tip: Use 'view -t <file.tar>' to inspect the contents of a TAR archive without extracting it.

name: alias
desc: Creates custom persistent command shortcuts
definition:
Defines and stores command shortcuts (aliases) that persist across sessions.

Usage:
  alias                       → lists all saved aliases
  alias name='command'        → creates a new persistent alias

Examples:
  alias ll='ls -l'
  alias gs='git status'

Details:
• Aliases are saved in a file named 'pynix_aliases.json' located in the same directory as your terminal.
• Automatically reloaded every time PyNixShell starts.
• Supports both single and double quotes for command definitions.
• Each alias behaves like a native built-in command once defined.

Tip: Use aliases to shorten frequently used commands and create your own custom shortcuts that persist between sessions.

name: date
desc: Displays the current date and time
definition:
Shows the system's current date and time in a human-readable format.

Usage:
  date              → displays the current date and time
  date -i           → displays date and time in ISO format (e.g., 2025-10-30T15:47:29)

Examples:
  date              → Thu Oct 30 15:47:29 2025
  date -i           → 2025-10-30T15:47:29.482191

Tip: Use this command to quickly check the system clock or timestamp events.

name: unalias
desc: Removes defined command aliases
definition:
Deletes one or all existing aliases from both memory and the persistent alias file.

Usage:
  unalias <name>       → removes a single alias
  unalias -a           → removes all aliases

Examples:
  unalias ll
  unalias -a

Details:
• Updates the same 'pynix_aliases.json' file located in the terminal's directory.
• Removed aliases take effect immediately.
• Works alongside the alias command for full control of your saved shortcuts.

Tip: Use 'unalias -a' to quickly clear all custom aliases and start fresh.

name: zip
desc: Creates a ZIP archive using native system compression tools
definition:
Compresses a folder or file into a .zip archive using your operating system's built-in tools.

Usage:
  zip <source_folder> <destination_name.zip>

Examples:
  zip MyProject backup.zip
  zip Documents Archive.zip

Details:
• On Windows, uses PowerShell's native Compress-Archive command.
• On macOS/Linux, uses the system 'zip' command if available.
• If unavailable, automatically falls back to Python's built-in shutil.make_archive.
• Preserves folder structure and file timestamps.

Tip: This provides the same result as right-clicking a folder and selecting “Send to → Compressed (zipped) folder.”

name: add
desc: Copies and installs a new Python command permanently
definition:
Usage: add <file.py>
Copies a Python command file into /commands/, loads it immediately, and ensures it auto-loads in future sessions. If a file with the same name exists, confirmation is requested before overwriting.

name: sudo
desc: Runs a Windows command as Administrator
definition:
Usage: sudo <windows_command>

Executes the specified Windows command with administrative privileges, similar to Linux 'sudo'.

When run, PyNixShell launches a PowerShell window with elevated rights to perform the command. Only available on Windows systems.

name: watch
desc: Repeats a command at regular intervals
definition:
Executes a specified command repeatedly at a defined time interval. Similar to the Unix `watch` command.

Usage:
  watch -n <seconds> <command>        → runs the command repeatedly every N seconds
  watch -n <seconds> -t <count> <command>  → runs the command N times total

Examples:
  watch -n 2 ls                       → runs `ls` every 2 seconds
  watch -n 5 -t 3 du                  → runs `du` every 5 seconds, three times total

Tip: Useful for monitoring changes in directories, system status, or running processes in real-time.
